resources.string: Are you sure you want to exit?

Detailed instructions:
The bench press is a classic exercise for developing strength and muscle mass in the chest. Follow these steps to perform it correctly:

Starting Position:

Lie on a flat bench with your feet flat on the floor.
Make sure the bar is aligned with your chest.
Grip:

Grab the bar with your hands slightly wider than shoulder width.
Keep your elbows bent at about 90 degrees.
Descent:

Lower the bar in a controlled manner towards your chest.
Keep your elbows close to your body.
Ascent: 

Push the bar up by extending your elbows.
Exhale during this movement.
Objectives and Muscles Worked:\nThe bench press focuses mainly on the development of the pectoralis major, triceps and anterior deltoid muscles. It is essential for improving upper body strength.

Necessary Equipment:

· Flat bench
· Bar and weights

Number of Recommended Sets and Repetitions:

3 sets of 8-12 repetitions.


Rest between Sets:

Rest 3 to 5 minutes between each set.


Recommended Frequency:
 
Include exercise in your training routine 1-2 times a week.

Objectives and Muscles Worked:

The free squat is a complete exercise that works the muscles of the legs, including the quadriceps, hamstrings and glutes. In addition, it strengthens the lower back and core.

Detailed Instructions:

The free squat is a fundamental exercise to work the muscles of the legs and glutes. Follow these steps to do it correctly:


Starting Position:

- Stand with your feet at shoulder height.
- If you are using a bar, place it on your shoulders, keeping your back straight.


Descent:

- Bend your knees and hips, as if you were going to sit in an imaginary chair.
- Go down until your thighs are parallel to the floor or according to your range of motion. 


Ascent:

- Push with your heels to return to the starting position.
- Remember to keep your back straight and abdomen contracted throughout the movement.
Targets and Muscles Worked:\n\nThe Seal Row focuses on the development of the back, specifically the upper muscles, such as the trapezius and rhomboids. It also works the rear deltoids.

Detailed Instructions:

The Seal Row is an effective exercise for developing the back and deltoid muscles. Follow these steps to do it correctly:


Starting Position:

Lie face down on a horizontal bench, so that your chest is suspended in the air.
Adjust the bench so that your feet are firmly supported on the ground.


Grip:

Grasp the bar with your hands slightly wider than shoulder width.
Keep your elbows bent at about 90 degrees.


Lifting:

Raise your Bar up, bringing your elbows back and squeezing your shoulder blades.
Make sure you maintain good posture and control the movement at all times.


Lowing:

Lower the bar in a controlled manner to the starting position.
